page.title: 03History Shenington/Alkerton
page.content: Shenington appears twice in the Domesday book. The derivation of the name being village on the shining hill, it originally being Senendone. The Saxons ploughed the land in terraced steps. There is evidence of Roman settlement, a coin being found in 1984 and a Roman Whorl more recently. In the Civil War Shenington was a King's village. On May 13 1721 Shenington suffered a fire, some houses being rebuilt. In 1844 Shenington became part of Oxfordshire (prior to that it had been Gloucestershire). Alkerton has always been a small village. In 1641 there were 29 men over the age of 18. In 1969 there were 22 men over this age. At the time of the Civil War it was often pilaged by the Parliamentarians of Banbury.
